oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First (Colored) Baptist Church: interior
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 709 Martin Luther King Jr. St, Selma, Dallas County, AL

Color photograph of the interior of a church with a high vaulted ceiling. Pews curve around the chancel. A pipe organ is behind the pulpit and choir seats. The room is lit by tall windows with a pointed arch.

First Baptist Colored Church (now First Baptist Church) was formally established in 1866 as the first black Baptist church in Selma. During Reconstruction other churches formed across the city of Selma but First Baptist maintained its leadership. In 1871 and 1872 state black Baptist conventions took place at the church, acknowledging its role not only locally but in the general Baptist movement in Alabama. A large brick church building was constructed in 1894 in northeast Selma. The church served as an important strategy center and meeting place for the Civil Rights Movement in Selma in the early 1960s. In 1965 it was a staging ground for the Selma to Montgomery March led by Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr., with support from the Southern Christian Leadership Council (SCLC) and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC).
